an5.133:1.1: “Mendicants, even a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king, does not wield power without having their own king.”
an5.133:1.2: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,
an5.133:1.3: “But who is the king of the wheel-turning monarch, the just and principled king?”
an5.133:1.4: “It is principle, monk,” said the Buddha.
an5.133:2.1: “Monk, a wheel-turning monarch provides just protection and security for his court, relying only on principle—honoring, respecting, and venerating principle, having principle as his flag, banner, and authority.
an5.133:3.1: He provides just protection and security for his aristocrats, vassals, troops, brahmins and householders, people of town and country, ascetics and brahmins, beasts and birds.
an5.133:3.2: When he has done this, he wields power only in a principled manner.
an5.133:3.3: And this power cannot be undermined by any human enemy.
an5.133:4.1: In the same way, monk, a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, a just and principled king, provides just protection and security for the monks, relying only on principle—honoring, respecting, and venerating principle, having principle as his flag, banner, and authority.
an5.133:4.2: ‘This kind of bodily action should be cultivated. This kind of bodily action should not be cultivated.
an5.133:4.3: This kind of verbal action should be cultivated. This kind of verbal action should not be cultivated.
an5.133:4.4: This kind of mental action should be cultivated. This kind of mental action should not be cultivated.
an5.133:4.5: This kind of livelihood should be cultivated. This kind of livelihood should not be cultivated.
an5.133:4.6: This kind of market town should be cultivated. This kind of market town should not be cultivated.’
an5.133:5.1: In the same way, monk, a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, a just and principled king, provides just protection and security for the nuns … laymen … laywomen, relying only on principle—honoring, respecting, and venerating principle, having principle as his flag, banner, and authority.
an5.133:5.2: ‘This kind of bodily action should be cultivated. This kind of bodily action should not be cultivated.
an5.133:5.3: This kind of verbal action should be cultivated. This kind of verbal action should not be cultivated.
an5.133:5.4: This kind of mental action should be cultivated. This kind of mental action should not be cultivated.
an5.133:5.5: This kind of livelihood should be cultivated. This kind of livelihood should not be cultivated.
an5.133:5.6: This kind of market town should be cultivated. This kind of market town should not be cultivated.’
an5.133:6.1: When a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha has provided just protection and security for the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen, he rolls forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma only in a principled manner.
an5.133:6.2: And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world.”
